title: China Development Bank provides $18.3 million loan for Phase II of the Djibouti Telecommunication Network Expansion and Renovation Project (Linked to Project ID#421)
description: Between September 24, 2006 and September 26, 2006, during a Djibouti government delegation's trip to Shenzhen, representatives from China Development Bank (CDB) and Djibouti Télécom signed a $18,290,000 loan agreement for Phase II of the Djibouti Telecommunication Network Expansion and Renovation Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown.  Phase II of the Djibouti Telecommunication Network Expansion and Renovation Project reportedly involved the acquisition of IN \ NSS \ BSS \ NGN equipment, optimization of GSM signals, and and expansion of the country’s existing network capacity. Huawei was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was completed on June 20, 2007 and an official ribbon-cutting ceremony took place shortly thereafter on June 26, 2007.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Djibouti Télécom Project or GSM Mobile Expansion Project. The Chinese project title is 吉布提电信公司GSM移动扩容项目.2. Phase I, which was financed by China Eximbank, is captured via Project ID#421.3. On September 8, 2006, ZTE Corporation issued an RMB 50 million joint liability loan guarantee for a term of 12 years.  This guarantee was presumably in support of Phases I and II of this project, as it was Djibouti Telecom's most important and expensive venture at the time.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Development Bank provides $18.3 million loan for Phase II of the Djibouti Telecommunication Network Expansion and Renovation Project (Linked to Project ID#421)

# Description
Between September 24, 2006 and September 26, 2006, during a Djibouti government delegation's trip to Shenzhen, representatives from China Development Bank (CDB) and Djibouti Télécom signed a $18,290,000 loan agreement for Phase II of the Djibouti Telecommunication Network Expansion and Renovation Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown.  Phase II of the Djibouti Telecommunication Network Expansion and Renovation Project reportedly involved the acquisition of IN \ NSS \ BSS \ NGN equipment, optimization of GSM signals, and and expansion of the country’s existing network capacity. Huawei was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was completed on June 20, 2007 and an official ribbon-cutting ceremony took place shortly thereafter on June 26, 2007.
justification: Project focuses on telecommunications network expansion and renovation, which is unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Telecommunication network expansion, acquisition of telecom equipment, network capacity expansion

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Conference Car Project
description: On 31 August, 2006, a Chinese embassy official and the Djibouti Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation signed letters of exchange in which China committed to donating conference cars to the Government of Djibouti (Chinese project title is 吉布提会议用车项目). The value of the donation is unknown. The cars were officially handed over to the Djibouti side on 3 December 2006.

The value of the donation is unknown. The cars were officially handed over to the Djibouti side on 3 December 2006.

title: Chinese Government donates anti-malaria drugs to Djibouti via Letters of Exchange agreement
description: On 27 August and 13 September 2006, Chinese and Djibouti government officials signed an Exchange of Letters agreement in which China committed to donating anti-malaria drugs to Djibouti.  On December 5, 2007, the handover ceremony for the anti-malarial drug project was held at the Djibouti Ministry of Health's Drug Procurement Center. The handover certificate was signed by the Chinese Ambassador Wang Xiaodu and the Secretary General of the Djibouti Ministry of Health, Sareh Banoi Taouha.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates anti-malaria drugs to Djibouti via Letters of Exchange agreement

# Description
On 27 August and 13 September 2006, Chinese and Djibouti government officials signed an Exchange of Letters agreement in which China committed to donating anti-malaria drugs to Djibouti.  On December 5, 2007, the handover ceremony for the anti-malarial drug project was held at the Djibouti Ministry of Health's Drug Procurement Center. The handover certificate was signed by the Chinese Ambassador Wang Xiaodu and the Secretary General of the Djibouti Ministry of Health, Sareh Banoi Taouha.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Anti-malaria drug donation, healthcare sector focus

title: Chinese Government loans EC$3,317,431 to Dominica Agricultural Industrial and Development Bank for on-lending activities
description: In Fiscal Year 2006, Dominica Agricultural Industrial and Development Bank — a bank that is majority-owned by the Government of the Commonwealth of Dominica (GOCD) — borrowed EC$3,317,431  from China Eximbank to support on-lending activities. The loan was guaranteed by the GOCD.
staff_comments: 1. The 2006 annual report of the Dominica Agricultural Industrial and Development Bank identifies the ‘Republic of China’ as the lender. However, given that Dominica severed diplomatic ties with Taiwan in May 2004, the lender is almost certainly the People’s Republic of China (PRC). Reporting by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) corroborates the existence of a lending relationship between the PRC and Dominica Agricultural Industrial and Development Bank. 2. The precise financial commitment date is unknown. However, it is known that the EC$3,317,431  borrowing took place between July 1, 2005 and June 30, 2006. 3. For evidence that the lender is China Eximbank, see https://www.dropbox.com/s/jwlm7akcczpmbgr/New%20AID%20Bank%20Chairman%20outlines%20plans%20for%20the%20bank%20-%20GIS%20Dominica.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/jntz051chitv5pp/Rationale%20-%20Dominica%20AID%20Bank%20June%204%2C%202013%282%29.pdf?dl=0. 4. This China Eximbank loan is not captured in the China-Latin America Finance Database, which is co-produced by the Inter-American Dialogue and Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center.” Add these sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/jwlm7akcczpmbgr/New%20AID%20Bank%20Chairman%20outlines%20plans%20for%20the%20bank%20-%20GIS%20Dominica.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/jntz051chitv5pp/Rationale%20-%20Dominica%20AID%20Bank%20June%204%2C%202013%282%29.pdf?dl=0
combined_text:
# Sector
BANKING AND FINANCIAL SERVICES

# Title

# Description
In Fiscal Year 2006, Dominica Agricultural Industrial and Development Bank — a bank that is majority-owned by the Government of the Commonwealth of Dominica (GOCD) — borrowed EC$3,317,431  from China Eximbank to support on-lending activities. The loan was guaranteed by the GOCD.
justification: Project involves financial services with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Loan for on-lending activities through a development bank, no specific environmental or energy-related activities mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides 20 million RMB grant for Mobile Container Inspection Equipment for Guayaquil Port Authority through ETCA
description: On January 12, 2006, the Chinese Ambassador to Ecuador and Ecuador's Foreign Minister signed an exchange of letters, which committed grant funding for the Mobile Container Inspection Equipment Project, worth 20 million RMB. The purpose of the project was to acquire and install mobile container inspection equipment (un equipo móvil de inspección de contenedores), in Guayaquil Port, to be used by the Guayaquil Port Authority.   It was funded through the 20 million RMB grant provided in an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) signed November 17, 2005.  The equipment was to be manufactured by the Chinese company NUCTECH Company Limited. Additionally, in the Letters of Exchange, the Chinese government agreed to send a team of technicians to Ecuador to help with installation, recalibration, and training associated with the project.  The Chinese government began transporting the equipment on October 15, 2006. The equipment was officially handed over on December 11, 2006 in Guayaquil.  The project is also referred to as "Equipos de rayos x para contenedores" in Spanish. The Chinese project title is 厄瓜多尔一台移动式集装箱检测设备项目.
staff_comments: The ETCA that funded this project, signed November 17, 2005, has not been coded as a separate umbrella project, due to the entire grant amount provided very likely funding this project exclusively. It has been assumed that the project cost is 20 million RMB. According to 'La Cooperación Bilateral Ecuador-China...', the project cost was 2,537,468.50 USD. An exchange rate between USD and RMB of approximately 1:7.8818 would result in this project cost being equivalent to 20 million RMB, which would have been the exchange rate on either October 27 or 30, 2006 (per https://www.poundsterlinglive.com/bank-of-england-spot/historical-spot-exchange-rates/usd/USD-to-CNY-2006). It has therefore been assumed that the full grant provided in November 2005 was used for the project due to (1) the extreme closeness in these two transaction amounts, accounting for the exchange rate around the time of project implementation, and (2) the fact that other projects listed the tables seem to have their amounts reflect the values of the projects at the time they were implemented, not when the table was complied (see, for example, project 'Medicamentos para prevención del dengue' which was said to be worth 500,000 USD in the table and in the Letters of Exchange from 2005). 'La Cooperación Bilateral Ecuador-China...' is an academic source that cites, for this transaction amount, a now-inaccessible Ecuador government website. Parts of the website are accessible via Wayback Machine, though not the exact link cited.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRADE POLICIES AND REGULATIONS

# Title
Chinese Government provides 20 million RMB grant for Mobile Container Inspection Equipment for Guayaquil Port Authority through ETCA

# Description
On January 12, 2006, the Chinese Ambassador to Ecuador and Ecuador's Foreign Minister signed an exchange of letters, which committed grant funding for the Mobile Container Inspection Equipment Project, worth 20 million RMB. The purpose of the project was to acquire and install mobile container inspection equipment (un equipo móvil de inspección de contenedores), in Guayaquil Port, to be used by the Guayaquil Port Authority.   It was funded through the 20 million RMB grant provided in an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) signed November 17, 2005.  The equipment was to be manufactured by the Chinese company NUCTECH Company Limited. Additionally, in the Letters of Exchange, the Chinese government agreed to send a team of technicians to Ecuador to help with installation, recalibration, and training associated with the project.  The Chinese government began transporting the equipment on October 15, 2006. The equipment was officially handed over on December 11, 2006 in Guayaquil.  The project is also referred to as "Equipos de rayos x para contenedores" in Spanish. The Chinese project title is 厄瓜多尔一台移动式集装箱检测设备项目.
justification: Project focuses on port inspection equipment without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Mobile container inspection equipment for port operations, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese government funds medical team with acupuncturist, massage therapist to Ministry of Foreign Relations Medical Center in Ecuador
description: On January 12, 2006, the governments of China and Ecuador signed Letters of Exchange, in which the Chinese government committed to send a medical mission to the Ministry of Foreign Relations Medical Center (Centro Médico del Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores del Ecuador). At the medical center, the team was to provide medical services to different public institutions in Ecuador.   The team would consist of two doctors, one an acupuncturist and the other a massage therapist, as well as an interpreter. The costs associated with the mission, including the salaries of the experts, their travel, cost of living, cost of medicines, and administrative costs would be covered by the Chinese government and were worth 720,000 RMB. Various other costs were the responsibility of the government of Ecuador.  The Letters specified the team would stay in Ecuador for one year, but the start and and dates of the mission are unknown.
combined_text:

The team would consist of two doctors, one an acupuncturist and the other a massage therapist, as well as an interpreter. The costs associated with the mission, including the salaries of the experts, their travel, cost of living, cost of medicines, and administrative costs would be covered by the Chinese government and were worth 720,000 RMB. justification: Project focuses on providing healthcare services without clear environmental or energy transition impacts

title: Andes Petroleum funds Andes Cocoa Garden Project in Ecuador
description: In 2006, Andes Petroleum, a subsidiary of CNPC, funded the Andes Cocoa Garden Project in Ecuador. Through the project, Andes Petroleum provides  mobile medical team and school buses for local communities in Ecuador. As of 2015, the project resolved the commuting problems for 500 or more students whose homes are far from their schools.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Andes Petroleum funds Andes Cocoa Garden Project in Ecuador

# Description
In 2006, Andes Petroleum, a subsidiary of CNPC, funded the Andes Cocoa Garden Project in Ecuador. Through the project, Andes Petroleum provides  mobile medical team and school buses for local communities in Ecuador. As of 2015, the project resolved the commuting problems for 500 or more students whose homes are far from their schools.
justification: Project focuses on social development through education and healthcare services without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Mobile medical team, school buses, focus on student commuting issues

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 35 million grant for Fishery and Aquaculture Center Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#58829)
description: On November 11, 2006, the Chinese Government and the Government of Egypt signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed RMB 50 million of grant funding for the Fishery and Aquaculture Center Construction Project and the Freedom Experimental School Construction Project (see Project ID#58829). China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) subsequently approved an RMB 35 million grant for the Fishery and Aquaculture Center Construction Project and drew the grant proceeds from the November 11, 2006 ETCA.   This project involved the construction of a Fishery and Aquaculture Center (معهد الإستزراع السمكي وتكنولوجيا الاسماك) at Suez Canal University.   The center occupies 4540 square meters and it includes a teaching and training center, a laboratory building, seed incubation center, and bait cultivation workshop. It is located on Suez Canal University's old campus. In total the Fishery and Aquaculture Center occupies 4540 square meters.   China's Fishing Engineering Institute, a research department of China's Ministry of Agriculture, was responsible for project design. Guangzhou Wanan Construction Supervision Co. and Xinjiang International Economic Cooperation Corporation were the contractors responsible for project implementation. The project was constructed in two phases and it involved technical guidance from China's Fisheries Engineering Institute.   A groundbreaking ceremony took place on May 16, 2011. Then, on November 6, 2012, the construction of the center was completed after passing a final MOFCOM inspection. The center is now called the Fish Farming and Technology Institute and it officially opened in May 2014.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Aquaculture Laboratory at Suez Canal University. The Chinese project title is 士运河大学渔业与水产教学培训中心项目. The Arabic project title is معهد الإستزراع السمكي وتكنولوجيا الاسماك or معمل للاستزراع السمكى فى جامعة قناة السويس.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 35 million grant for Fishery and Aquaculture Center Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#58829)

# Description
On November 11, 2006, the Chinese Government and the Government of Egypt signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed RMB 50 million of grant funding for the Fishery and Aquaculture Center Construction Project and the Freedom Experimental School Construction Project (see Project ID#58829). China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) subsequently approved an RMB 35 million grant for the Fishery and Aquaculture Center Construction Project and drew the grant proceeds from the November 11, 2006 ETCA.   This project involved the construction of a Fishery and Aquaculture Center (معهد الإستزراع السمكي وتكنولوجيا الاسماك) at Suez Canal University.   The center occupies 4540 square meters and it includes a teaching and training center, a laboratory building, seed incubation center, and bait cultivation workshop. It is located on Suez Canal University's old campus. In total the Fishery and Aquaculture Center occupies 4540 square meters.   China's Fishing Engineering Institute, a research department of China's Ministry of Agriculture, was responsible for project design. Guangzhou Wanan Construction Supervision Co. and Xinjiang International Economic Cooperation Corporation were the contractors responsible for project implementation. The project was constructed in two phases and it involved technical guidance from China's Fisheries Engineering Institute.   A groundbreaking ceremony took place on May 16, 2011. Then, on November 6, 2012, the construction of the center was completed after passing a final MOFCOM inspection. The center is now called the Fish Farming and Technology Institute and it officially opened in May 2014.
justification: Project focuses on education and research in fishery and aquaculture without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of teaching/training center, laboratory, and research facilities at university campus

title: Chinese Government cancels $17.12 million of the Government of Equatorial Guinea’s outstanding obligations
description: In 2006, Li Zhaoxing, China’s Foreign Minister, traveled to Africa, visiting Chad, Benin, Mozambique, the Central African Republic, Equatorial Guinea and Eritrea. During this trip, he signed a debt cancellation agreement with the Government of Equatorial Guinea. Neither party disclosed the amount of debt that was forgiven.  However, the IMF reported that the agreement forgave debts resulting from previously contracted interest-free loans (with maturity dates on or before December 31, 2005), reducing the Government of Equatorial Guinea’s outstanding debt obligations to the Chinese Government by approximately 50%. The IMF also recorded a reduction in the Government of Equatorial Guinea’s outstanding debt obligations to the Chinese Government — from $33 million in 2005 to $15.88 million in 2006. Therefore, AidData estimates the value of the debts that were forgiven as $17.12 million.
staff_comments: The debts that were written off through this agreement were almost certainly contracted before 2000, so AidData has not coded this project as an “umbrella project” (as there is little risk of double-counting loans that were contracted from 2000 onward).
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
Chinese Government cancels $17.12 million of the Government of Equatorial Guinea’s outstanding obligations

# Description
In 2006, Li Zhaoxing, China’s Foreign Minister, traveled to Africa, visiting Chad, Benin, Mozambique, the Central African Republic, Equatorial Guinea and Eritrea. During this trip, he signed a debt cancellation agreement with the Government of Equatorial Guinea. Neither party disclosed the amount of debt that was forgiven.  However, the IMF reported that the agreement forgave debts resulting from previously contracted interest-free loans (with maturity dates on or before December 31, 2005), reducing the Government of Equatorial Guinea’s outstanding debt obligations to the Chinese Government by approximately 50%. The IMF also recorded a reduction in the Government of Equatorial Guinea’s outstanding debt obligations to the Chinese Government — from $33 million in 2005 to $15.88 million in 2006. Therefore, AidData estimates the value of the debts that were forgiven as $17.12 million.
justification: Debt cancellation agreement with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Debt forgiveness of $17.12 million, no project development or infrastructure involved
